page.title: 02SOUTH CERNEY ARMY CAMP
page.content:
South Cerney Army Camp occupies 367 acres of land. As the camp was originally built in 1935 as a R.A.F. Flying Training School, it also has an airfield which takes up 200 acres. There is no permanent runway as it is a grass airfield, and is still used by No.625 Volunteer Gliding Squadron. In 1971 South Cerney was taken over by the Army, and is the headquarters for the 29 Transport and Movements Regiments of the Royal Corps of Transport, and also No.2 Postal and Courier detachment of the Royal Engineers. Although 300 people work on the camp, it can accommodate 3,000 when necessary in its role in troop movements.
(continued on page 3).
